content.description: Ascend a series of wave-like features on the rock with good crimps.
content.location: This is the third bolted route from the left.

content.description: This was most likely one of the first routes established on Blob Rock.  It runs right up the middle through some wavy features and then through a blocky corner.
content.location:
This route sits to the right of

Great Blob

and in between the current sport routes.

content.description:
Follow bolts to a rest stance below a polished face to the left, and climb a few features up and right. This tricky thing moves on to the face left and then straight up slab to anchors. Its name comes from near splits move with left leg on to face.

Per

Nick L.

: this route is overhung and juggy to the first bolt. After clipping the bolt, you can go right or left (right is better climbing). Use a couple crimpy holds to the right to second bolt. There are easy moves up to third bolt where the crux starts. There is a good place for a heel hook, and then ascend a couple crimps up to the fourth bolt and up to the anchors.
content.location:
This route is 3rd from the left.

Per

Nick L.

: this route is the second set of bolts from climber's left.

content.description:
The top anchors are one climb left of the

Standard Route

. These two climbs sit between the current bolted sport routes. For good fun, this route can be lead on gear.
content.protection: 1 set of Aliens and 1 green #0.75 Camalot.

content.description: Start in the same spot as the route to the left, but move right after clipping the first bolt. Climb an interesting crack for 10-15 feet.
content.protection: 4 bolts to a two bolt anchor.
content.location: This is the fourth bolted line from the left.

content.description: The name and grade comes from the Steamboat Springs Rock Guide. It sits in between the current bolted routes on the left side of Blob Rock. It starts with fun overhanging jugs and then goes through a funky flake/crack up to the anchors that are shared with the bolted route to the right.
content.protection: The anchors are shared with the sport route on the right. It is usually toproped, but I have heard that it has been lead on gear. I am unsure of the requirements, but it is definitely thin.
content.location: This is the second route from the left side of Blob Rock.

content.description: Move up easy rock to a bulging crack crux. It is a little dirty.
content.protection: There are anchors for toproping. It could be led on gear if you like a little spice in your life.
content.location:
This route sits between "

I Should Have Done Yoga

" and "

Great Blob

".

content.description: Far Left is pretty consistent without big rests. The crux is mid-wall. It has fun, mostly small, steep moves up to a slab finish.
content.protection: 4 bolts and a two bolt anchor.
content.location: It is the furthest left route on Blob Rock.
